instruction: How does the semi-supervised support vector machine (GS3VM) incorporate both labeled and unlabeled oil samples in the classification between swill-cooked dirty oil and edible oil using NIR spectroscopy?
Output:
The semi-supervised support vector machine (GS3VM) incorporates both labeled and unlabeled oil samples in the classification between swill-cooked dirty oil and edible oil using NIR spectroscopy by utilizing the manifold assumption and approximating the distribution of spectra from both types of samples. 

In the GS3VM approach, the labeled oil samples are used to create a traditional supervised classification model, such as support vector machine (SVM), which is trained using the available labeled data. However, since the number of labeled samples is often limited, the GS3VM also incorporates the unlabeled oil samples to improve the classification performance.

The GS3VM assumes that the labeled and unlabeled samples lie on a low-dimensional manifold in the feature space. It uses the labeled samples to estimate the manifold structure and then propagates this information to the unlabeled samples. By doing so, the GS3VM is able to make predictions for the unlabeled samples based on their proximity to the labeled samples on the manifold.

By incorporating the unlabeled samples, the GS3VM is able to capture the complex linear and nonlinear relationships between the class labels (swill-cooked dirty oil and edible oil) and the spectral distribution. This helps improve the prediction results when there is insufficient training information available.
